question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In my Intro to Evolutionary Anthropology course, I developed a deeper understanding of how humans evolved both biologically and culturally over time. I learned about key fossil discoveries, like Australopithecus afarensis and Homo erectus, which helped me understand the branching nature of human evolution. I also gained experience using the scientific method to analyze fossil evidence and test hypotheses about early human behavior. One of the most interesting insights was learning how culture and biology interact—for example, how the development of tools and symbolic thought played a major role in shaping who we are today. This course changed how I think about human origins.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about evolutionary anthropology, which was previously an area that I had not explored before.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
The concept of racism and how it is a misconception because ultimately we are all the same but race was created by society and white men of power.
How there are different forms of primates such as humans, apes, chimps, monkeys, lemurs, lorises and tarsiers. How uniquely similar yet different they all are.
The difference between genetics, epigentics, DNA and much more that relates to our history.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One concept that I learned, which I believed to be very useful, was the R learning language. I'm a CS major, and I had no previous experience with the R programming language, so learning it in this class was very insightful and interesting in the field I'm interested in learning. Other concepts, such as genetics and evolution, were some of which I found very interesting. Genetics was used to amplify agendas with the research done with it, and notifying all the good and bad things about studying genetics was insightful to learn. Evolution as well; learning how humans evolved to be who we are today was something I expected from this class, but the degree of depth we covered the content was very insightful and enlightening as well.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I had never been exposed to the field of evolutionary anthropology prior to Duke, so it was very exciting to learn these fundamental concepts for the first time. I learned that understanding evolution can still have implications for the way we understand human health and functioning today, that evolution is not a straight line, and that we can draw upon knowledge from our living primate family members to continue to inform research in this field.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class was definitely a lecture course…every day we came in, sat down, and listened to Dr. Pontzer lecture from a PowerPoint. The consistency was great! And despite the seemingly monotonous structure of the course, Dr. Pontzer managed to make every lesson engaging and fun for students. Even though he was teaching from a PowerPoint, Dr. Pontzer frequently involved students by asking questions, opening the floor up for discussions, or having us participate in some sort of interactive challenge to prove a point he was teaching about. Dr. Pontzer was always very clear about what to expect on the exams and I found all the exams to be fair…not too difficult but not too easy.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

It gave me a much deeper understanding of how forensic anthropologists work and their impact on the world of criminal justice.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The instructors did a great job and adapting to the class' needs when certain teaching strategies weren't working. For example, the instructors made sure to shorten the slides and give more time in lab so that students could get hands-on experience. The instructors were very engaged in interacting with each student and giving everyone an opportunity to give answers, make mistakes, and learn from them. The instructors also rotated throughout lab often to spend time with all lab groups and give really valuable assistance, advice, etc. 
I would definitely keep the review sessions (as a game in teams!) the class before exams, these were really helpful for my studying. I also hope that the lab component will still be at least half the class period, because it was my favorite part about this class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I highly recommend this course, even if you're a beginner to anatomy and physiology (because I also was!) It's a lot of work and can feel overwhelming at the beginning, but if you keep up with the content and engage a lot in lab, it actually all comes together pretty smoothly. The exams are mostly memorization, which flashcards and lab help a lot with, and you learn a lot of really cool clinical correlations. It's also the only class at Duke right now where you get to have firsthand experience doing a dissection on a cadaver!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The instructors did a great job and adapting to the class' needs when certain teaching strategies weren't working. For example, the instructors made sure to shorten the slides and give more time in lab so that students could get hands-on experience. The instructors were very engaged in interacting with each student and giving everyone an opportunity to give answers, make mistakes, and learn from them. The instructors also rotated throughout lab often to spend time with all lab groups and give really valuable assistance, advice, etc. 
I would definitely keep the review sessions (as a game in teams!) the class before exams, these were really helpful for my studying. I also hope that the lab component will still be at least half the class period, because it was my favorite part about this class.

response_text: The instructors were incredibly helpful and dedicated to our learning the entire semester. In every regard, they were engaged with us, and we engaged with them. They made learning fun and made the anatomy of lower extremities class the highlight of my day. For the future, I would keep hands-on team-based aspect of the cadaver lab a part of the course, as well as the reviews before exams.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I highly recommend this course, even if you're a beginner to anatomy and physiology (because I also was!) It's a lot of work and can feel overwhelming at the beginning, but if you keep up with the content and engage a lot in lab, it actually all comes together pretty smoothly. The exams are mostly memorization, which flashcards and lab help a lot with, and you learn a lot of really cool clinical correlations. It's also the only class at Duke right now where you get to have firsthand experience doing a dissection on a cadaver!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The instructors did a great job and adapting to the class' needs when certain teaching strategies weren't working. For example, the instructors made sure to shorten the slides and give more time in lab so that students could get hands-on experience. The instructors were very engaged in interacting with each student and giving everyone an opportunity to give answers, make mistakes, and learn from them. The instructors also rotated throughout lab often to spend time with all lab groups and give really valuable assistance, advice, etc. 
I would definitely keep the review sessions (as a game in teams!) the class before exams, these were really helpful for my studying. I also hope that the lab component will still be at least half the class period, because it was my favorite part about this class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors were incredibly helpful and dedicated to our learning the entire semester. In every regard, they were engaged with us, and we engaged with them. They made learning fun and made the anatomy of lower extremities class the highlight of my day. For the future, I would keep hands-on team-based aspect of the cadaver lab a part of the course, as well as the reviews before exams.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Evolutionary Psychology, the work of Brian Hare, and the cognitive abilities of apes (particularly chimpanzees).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about different lenses to look at human evolution by using Tinbergen's 4 levels of explanation. Additionally, understanding the natural fallacies that people sometimes used to combat policies or political ideologies. Lastly, the idea that evolution happened to benefit an individual and not a group was something I didn't know before.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learning about the history of cognition, and how apes are different/similar to humans.

response_text:
1. history of human and ape evolution

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how to apply knowledge about evolution to our cognition, a lot more about our ape cousins, and how much we can learn about ourselves from other species.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

Memorization of content

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) Tinbergen's 4 levels of analysis 
2) Differentiation between human and other primates' brains 
3) Examples of chimpanzee culture

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
-I learned more cognitive studies about primates
-I learned how to understand lecture talks 
-I learned differences between primates

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned about the different aspects of primate cognition. We mostly looked at that of apes, chimps, bonobos, and also humans. We covered topics such as the theory of mind, the puzzle of human cognition, phylogenetic trees, evolution, group selection, cognitive approaches, and much much more.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how we can use Tinbergen's four levels of analysis to help explain human cognitive evolution, grew in my reading and research skills on what studies have been published to expand on our understanding of human development, and adapted my thinking to value both the simplistic and complex mechanisms of the brain.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained a lot of insight into the factors underlying the development of modern human evolution. I also learned about the field of EvAnth, which I hadn't explored previously.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I am an intended neuroscience major and had never really been exposed to the ideas of evanth as a discipline. I learned the evolutionary origins of humans, the role our brains played in our survival as a species, and learned the applications of evanth of the brain, and how the ideas discussed in class can be applied to current events.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Thinking about HCE as a quantifiable and experimental thing, learning about human evolution by comparing to other primates, and learning how to read papers

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the different pathways of human cognitive evolution (social, cultural, ecological), various issues surrounding cognitive research, and the cultural/behavioral practices of different primate species (especially bonobos).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned a lot about the intersection between evolutionary theories, cognition, and psychology in various primates 
2. I learned about a lot of different mindsets / approaches to investigating the causes of different phenomena, like Morgan's Canon and Tinbergen's 4 levels 
3. I gained insight about both the similarities and differences between humans and non-human primates, as well as similarities/differences among non-human primates (especially chimpanzees and bonobos)

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed the idea of thinking about subjects critically--open minded but skeptical, since even the theories that are proposed, do not necessarily mean that they are solid and indisputable--often, theories on human nature can have their flaws. I also learned how to read scientific papers more critically to extrapolate necessary data.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Cognitive abilities and evolution in apes and humans. Self-domestication of dogs, bonos, and humans. Different intelligence theories.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course helped me be more critical of studies we learn in the field of psychology, I learned the importance of thinking about the validity of studies and methods and when to question results. Another thing I learned is the importance of looking at chimpanzees and bonobos to better understand cognition in humans and other nonhuman primates. Lastly, I learned the skill of comparing across species and time.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed new ways to study. I went back to writing in my notebook and focusing on course objectives when studying for midterms. I learned about children developing new ways of thinking, and honestly I now realize the importance of patience with younger kids. I also learned about how different we think from other primates.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Cognitive evolution of humans and how we can develop insights on this by observing other animals, research methods for cognitive evolution, different theories for human cognitive evolution.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Prof. Feldblum was one of the greatest professors I have ever had. He is very passionate about what he does and does his best to engage his students on a Friday afternoon class by encouraging participation as much as he can. In addition, I often had theoretical questions or things about evanth I wanted to discuss after class, and I enjoyed how he would take 10-15 minutes to talk with me about some cool further applications of the things we were learning in class. I wouldn't change pretty much anything, especially the essay assignments. I think the structure of the essay assignments was very fun, and a great way for me to make a new friend as well as get exposed to the research going on at Duke. Finally, after fluching Prof. Feldblum with my friend, I was very impressed by his commitment and passion to the discipline.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I very much liked the fact that the slides along with notes were given to us so we could look back at them after class. If there would be anything I would critique or continue/edit for the next years would be to be more concise with the way lectures are given--some days I felt that the professor was instructive and helpful, other days it seemed to me that I could extract the same data if I had stayed home. I do not say this as advice to cut down the information in the presentations, but to expand on the more (But I can see how that would be difficult in this class since we are learning a more general knowledge of evolution...)

Ideally, you should study and review content a little bit every single day. If you need anatomy and physiology as a pre-requisite for grad school, I think that class would be fine in most cases, but check with the grad program. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say make the most of your study group. I was never the biggest fan of group studying before anatomy, but talking things out and hearing the ways in which your classmates understand things could help you see things differently and help you develop a deeper understanding of the material. I would also say be active in your studying. Whether that means practicing active recall techniques or drawing things out, it is very hard to remember all there is to know about anatomy if you merely passively engage with the content. So try your best to engage as much as you can with all the material in ways that are active and helpful for you.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- bone identification 
- anatomy of major bones in the body 
- forensic anthropology (how race, sex, and age are determined and what is collected and analyzed from a specimen) 
- ethics related to anthropology (discovering new remains from thousands of years ago, collections of skeletal remains) 
- bone and teeth development 
- how diet can impact teeth morphology 
- diseases and how they may be identified from skeletal remains 
This class went beyond just discussing bones and their features since we discussed how bones can tell us so much information (diet, lifestyle, age, death, etc).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned how to write a behavioral journal article. I had written journal articles for chemistry and microbiology but I hadn't done a behavioral study. 
I learned how to use various data collection methods and tools such as scan sampling, focal sampling, and how to use Pocket Observer and Excel for behavioral analysis. 
I learned how to create a presentation for a behavioral conference.

I feel much more confident about reading and writing a scientific paper now.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

response_text: The instructor fostered a really engaging and safe learning environment! question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be ready to do a significant amount of work, but this class is one of a kind! You spend most days out observing lemurs at the Duke Lemur Center, which is an experience you really can't get anywhere else. You will also learn how to write scientifically!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Try to take the observation phase of the class very seriously and do it as accurately as possible because at the end you discover a lot of cool things you don't expect from the animals.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is such a excellent course for building up research and research paper writing skills, I feel like I learned so much and gained lots of helpful resources created by the instructor. Also, it's a really nice course to take if you may be interested in field work or primatology! If you're worried about being overwhelmed by workload with other classes, I would be cautious since this class does involve lots of projects and time. However, it can be doable with overloading if you balance out your schedule well (which is what I did this semester).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to prefom reseach via several differnt methods for data collection. I also learned the importance of picking relavent sources for my papers and make my writing consinse. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I had not written a scientific research paper before this course and Dr. Digby set up this course in a way that made the process so much easier. We basically worked on different sections of the paper at different times—so one week we worked on the introduction and methods section, the following week, we worked on the data analysis and results section. We also used excel to analyze our data—I had not used excel before this class but I am now much more comfortable using it because Dr. Digby walks you through the process. Our TA, Erika, was also very helpful if we needed extra help with our data and trying to sort it properly. I also learned the differences between scan sampling and focal sampling for observing animals.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: primates and how to use excel

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: You learn SO MUCH simply by watching how the lemurs behave! That was my favorite aspect of this course--being able to spend long stretches of time in which your only responsibility is to meticulously watch and record lemur behavior. I also learned more about primate taxonomy and methods for studying animal behavior.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that the mode of instruction was great, lots of practicals and getting out in the field. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This was an absolutely wonderful class! I felt like I was able to learn a lot about lemurs, and many applicable skills about research writing that I have already been able to apply to my own research even though it is in an unrelated field. Dr. Digby is an excellent professor. I felt that the class was very well structured without being overstructured. Dr. Dibgy goes above and beyond for her students, covering the difficult subject of learning how to do research in a new field while making it accessible to all students. I am confident that this class will be one of my most memorable at Duke and the skills I have learned here will stay with me in my future research career.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The hypotheses project was definitely one of the most helpful assignments I have completed at Duke. It was very thorough and it presented a paradigm for my research I had never heard before. I really appreciated Dr. Digby's thorough feedback on everything--she is so smart and good at making suggestions to make things make more sense. I really appreciated that Dr. Digby knew how much time we were spending on our projects outside of class, so she was very open and honest about deadlines and what she expected of us. She made herself available!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor was very helpful in her feedback because it was very specific and tailored to my specific project. I liked the buildup assignments in the beginning that were smaller and more feasible. They were much more approachable and helped the general senior thesis project seem more manageable even though it was usually difficult.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Digby allowed us infinite revisions, which was super helpful. I revised my assignments probably about 3 times on average, and the lack of pressure of a one-time submission, as well as encouragement to resubmit, made my writing and work a lot better. I also like how the bibliography was very early on, having my citations on hand and organized was incredibly helpful. I also liked learning about all the benefits of being an "honors student," as I've basically been living in study carrells for the past semester.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned to use R for advanced statistical analysis, which has been crucial for analyzing complex evolutionary data. I gained a strong understanding of key statistical concepts, such as Bayesian models and regression analysis, and learned how to apply them practically to real datasets in evolutionary research. These skills have significantly enhanced my ability to approach research questions with rigorous statistical methods.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Only graduate students or undergraduates with a strong motivation to self-learn should take this class, as it relies heavily on the ability to teach yourself the class content from videos and the textbook outside of class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: There's a lot of self-learning involved in the course, and it would be helpful to come in with a decent amount of statistics experience.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would suggest that if you have a solid background in mathematics or programming, this course will be a great fit for you. However, if you don’t have any experience in statistics, it might be challenging. The course dives into advanced statistical methods, and while the instructor provides excellent support, a foundation in stats can really help you succeed. Overall, it’s a rewarding course that will provide valuable skills for anyone interested in evolutionary research and data analysis.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

what are the obstacles of being PhD student?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learn about:Using R for ecological data analysis: I learned to use R to analyze food web data and create statistical models.Mathematical representation of ecological relationships: I learned to express ecological interactions through mathematical models, which helped me understand ecosystem dynamics.Ecological interpretation of food webs: I developed the ability to interpret food web relationships and how they affect energy and nutrient flow in ecosystems.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Jean was incredibly engaging and a great teacher - he would always be sure to connect theory back to real ecology scenarios. I really appreciated the primers for linear algebra to preface some of the classes. I also really enjoyed the live Q&As

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor created an amazing learning environment, with clear explanations and examples that made complex concepts, like using R, easier to understand. The combination of lectures, hands-on exercises, and assignments allowed me to apply ecological theory to real-world situations, which I found incredibly valuable. I especially appreciated how the course helped me connect nature’s relationships to mathematical models. The instructor was incredibly fabulous in delivering the class.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was incredibly stimulating, even though it was tough at the beginning, and I honestly thought I might not be able to keep up. The clear structure, the challenging content, and the hands-on application of complex concepts kept me engaged. The difficulty actually made the learning experience more rewarding as I was able to overcome the challenges and gain a deeper understanding of the material.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the class format of having two papers and the jigsaw method of discussion. As with all discussion based classes, a few individuals tended to dominate the class and some did not speak for the whole class. Not sure how to improve that, as it is a perennial problem, but it maybe reminding students midway through the semester to try to speak every class not speak if you have been the main person talking the class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the fact that we always had one instructor sit in on the group discussion. I liked that they mostly let the students lead the discussion and only intervened when we had specific questions or wanted to guide us into a different direction.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the layout of the class - I thought the ways that we split into groups and were encouraged to summarize the paper to others who hadn't read the paper was helpful for recalling what I read about. Some weeks we didn't get to hear summaries of all of the papers, so I wonder if each group had to post a short (2-3 sentence) summary of their paper to Sakai for everyone to see would be helpful in the future. That way, everyone has *at least* a brief summary of each paper by the end of the course. I also appreciated the ways that Jim & Justin participated in discussion constructively - it always provided new & unique perspectives from people who have been in the field longer than I. I also felt satisfied by the topics that we covered!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: new topics that I don't often apply to my science - animal behavior/ conflict and thermal ecology stood out as topics that were highly interesting but things I rarely think about

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Effective scientific writing, increased understanding of plant ecology and biodiversity, ways of interpreting data

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The discussion groups being randomly set each class helped me to hear from other students who have very different backgrounds than I do and who I might not interact with otherwise.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the class format of having two papers and the jigsaw method of discussion. As with all discussion based classes, a few individuals tended to dominate the class and some did not speak for the whole class. Not sure how to improve that, as it is a perennial problem, but it maybe reminding students midway through the semester to try to speak every class not speak if you have been the main person talking the class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the fact that we always had one instructor sit in on the group discussion. I liked that they mostly let the students lead the discussion and only intervened when we had specific questions or wanted to guide us into a different direction.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the layout of the class - I thought the ways that we split into groups and were encouraged to summarize the paper to others who hadn't read the paper was helpful for recalling what I read about. Some weeks we didn't get to hear summaries of all of the papers, so I wonder if each group had to post a short (2-3 sentence) summary of their paper to Sakai for everyone to see would be helpful in the future. That way, everyone has *at least* a brief summary of each paper by the end of the course. I also appreciated the ways that Jim & Justin participated in discussion constructively - it always provided new & unique perspectives from people who have been in the field longer than I. I also felt satisfied by the topics that we covered!

response_text: I really like reading the classic papers

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Getting the know the literature of our PhD overarching topic was very helpful.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Group discussions are always stimulating, especially when the students are invested in the content! The way that different people got excited about different ideas or topics made this class stimulating and exciting!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you want to understand a wide breadth of ecology, take this class! Low commitment relative to the knowledge gained.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is a very interesting and helpful course to get an overview about how individuals to communities were established in the literature in the topic of ecology.

response_text: If you want to gain comprehensive background on ecological literature, this is the class for you! It is also a great class if you're trying to get better at reading papers and summarizing literature.
